Problem:
Analyze a complex function \\( z(t) = t^k e^{i\omega t} \\), where k is a non-negative integer and \\( \omega \\) is a real number representing angular frequency. We also consider the impact of Laplace transformation on this function, defined as \\( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\}(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} z(t) \, dt \\).

If an additional damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) (where \\( \alpha \\) is a positive real number) is introduced at some time \\( t_0 > 0 \\), will the Laplace transform of the modified function only depend on the original parameters k and \\( \omega \\)?
Explanation: Introducing a damping factor modifies the function to \\( z(t) = t^k e^{-(\alpha - i\omega)t} \\). The Laplace transform of this new function will not only depend on the original parameters but also significantly on the newly introduced \\( \alpha \\), as it changes the convergence and nature of the exponential term in the transform.
